The daily spot price of West Texas Inter: the U.S. benchmark, increased from $49.78 per barrel on Jan. 5 to $59.12 on Feb. 19, indicating a rise of 18.8%.
The daily price of Europe Brent crude: the global benchmark, also showed an upward trend, rising from $53.16 on Jan. 5 to $62.84 on Feb. 19, representing an increase of 18.2%.
Both benchmarks have not been in the: 25 range since May 2020, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, contradicting the claim.
Experts attribute the price increases to: COVID-19 demand recovery, OPEC production cuts, and a near-term tightening in supply.
